Feature: Are there definite or specific articles?
Comment: Can be marked with Px (Winkler 2011:66).

Feature: Do indefinite nominals commonly have indefinite articles?
Are there prenominal articles?
Are there postnominal articles?
Comment: Can be marked with Px (Winkler 2011:66).

Feature: What is the order of numeral and noun in the NP?
What is the order of adnominal demonstrative and noun?
Can adnominal property words occur discontinuously?
Are nominal conjunction and comitative expressed by different elements?
Comment: However, instrumental(-comitative) case "can be used as a coordination marker, coordinanting subjects (rarely direct objects or other arguments)" (Edygarova 2022:511).

Feature: Is there an inclusive/exclusive distinction?
Comment: The reflexive pronoun aśmeos is used as an inclusive 'we' ('I/we + hearer(s)'), while the personal pronoun mi cannot be used with the inclusive meaning.

Feature: Is there a gender distinction in independent 3rd person pronouns?
Is there a dual or unit augmented form (in addition to plural or augmented) for all person categories in the pronoun system?
Are there three or more distance contrasts in demonstratives?
Comment: There is only proximal vs. distal distinction: ta 'this (here)' vs. distal so 'that (there)'.

Feature: Do demonstratives show an elevation distinction?
Comment: There is only proximal vs. distal distinction: ta 'this (here)' vs. distal so 'that (there)'.

Feature: Do demonstratives show a visible-nonvisible distinction?
Comment: There is only proximal vs. distal distinction: ta 'this (here)' vs. distal so 'that (there)'.

Feature: Are there demonstrative classifiers?
Is there nonphonological allomorphy of noun number markers?
Are there several nouns (more than three) which are suppletive for number?
Comment: indirectly mentioned

Feature: Is there productive overt morphological singular marking on nouns?
Is there productive morphological dual marking on nouns?
Comment: indirectly mentioned; paired nouns like 'eyes', 'ears' usually appear in sg (see Winkler 2011:37).

Feature: Is there productive morphological plural marking on nouns?
Comment: There is allomorphy in the plural marking: the suffix -jos- is attached after consonants and the suffix -os- after vowels.

Feature: Is there an associative plural marker for nouns?
Comment: Simple plural marker can take this function.

Feature: Is there a productive morphological pattern for deriving an action/state noun from a verb?
Is there a productive morphological pattern for deriving an agent noun from a verb?
Is there a productive morphological pattern for deriving an object noun from a verb?
Is there a noun class/gender system where sex is a factor in class assignment?
Is there a noun class/gender system where shape is a factor in class assignment?
Is there a noun class/gender system where animacy is a factor in class assignment?
Is there a noun class/gender system where plant status is a factor in class assignment?
Are there numeral classifiers?
Are there possessive classifiers?
Is the adnominal possessive construction different for alienable and inalienable nouns?
Comment: Besides the morphological distinction, e.g. йырыд /jɨr-ɨd/ 'your head', vynyd /vin-ɨd/ 'your younger brother' vs. коркаед /korka-jed/ 'your house', there are differences regarding the constructions: inalienable N:NOM + N, alienable N:ELA + N

Feature: What is the pragmatically unmarked order of adnominal possessor noun and possessed noun?
Do core adjectives (defined semantically as property concepts such as value, shape, age, dimension) act like verbs in predicative position?
Do core adjectives (defined semantically as property concepts; value, shape, age, dimension) used attributively require the same morphological treatment as verbs?
Are there morphological cases for non-pronominal core arguments (i.e. S/A/P)?
Comment: Direct object: accusative case (following some semantic/grammatical conditions); indirect object: dative; agent: in some constructions marked with Instrumental, Dative, Genitive

Feature: Are there morphological cases for pronominal core arguments (i.e. S/A/P)?
Comment: Direct object: accusative case (following some semantic/grammatical conditions); indirect object: dative; agent: in some constructions marked with Dative and Genitive.

Feature: Are there morphological cases for oblique non-pronominal NPs (i.e. not S/A/P)?
Are there morphological cases for oblique independent personal pronouns (i.e. not S/A/P)?
Are there prepositions?
Comment: Prepositions are used only marginally; all in all there are three prepositions: bi̮den, koti̮r 'per, one by one' and og 'about'.

Feature: Are there postpositions?
Do verbs have prefixes/proclitics, other than those that ONLY mark A, S or O (do include portmanteau: A & S + TAM)?
Do verbs have suffixes/enclitics, other than those that ONLY mark A, S or O (do include portmanteau: A & S + TAM)?
Is there productive infixation in verbs?
Is there overt morphological marking of present tense on verbs?
Is there overt morphological marking on the verb dedicated to past tense?
Is there overt morphological marking on the verb dedicated to future tense?
Is a morphological distinction between perfective and imperfective aspect available on verbs?
Comment: Preterite I vs. Perfect (I), perfect expresses result while preterite doesn't entail such a meaning

Feature: Can the S argument be indexed by a suffix/enclitic on the verb in the simple main clause?
Can the S argument be indexed by a prefix/proclitic on the verb in the simple main clause?
Can the A argument be indexed by a suffix/enclitic on the verb in the simple main clause?
Comment: See also GB089.

Feature: Can the A argument be indexed by a prefix/proclitic on the verb in the simple main clause?
Can the P argument be indexed by a suffix/enclitic on the verb in the simple main clause?
Can the P argument be indexed by a prefix/proclitic on the verb in the simple main clause?
Are variations in marking strategies of core participants based on TAM distinctions?
Are variations in marking strategies of core participants based on verb classes?
Are variations in marking strategies of core participants based on person distinctions?
Can verb stems alter according to the person of a core participant?
Comment: Verb stems do not alter

Feature: Is there a benefactive applicative marker on the verb (including indexing)?
Is there an instrumental applicative marker on the verb (including indexing)?
Can the recipient in a ditransitive construction be marked like the monotransitive patient?
Comment: However, DO can be marked with Dative in constructions with verba dicendi and sentiendi like the recipient in a ditransitive construction.

Feature: Can standard negation be marked by an affix, clitic or modification of the verb?
Is there directional or locative morphological marking on verbs?
Comment: Only lexicalized cases like ber-e kylyny (lit. 'stay in the back') + ACC or ABL 'to be late, miss' (Winkler 2011:127), uli karyny (lit. 'to do/make below') (ibid.:128)

Feature: Is there verb suppletion for participant number?
Is there verb suppletion for tense or aspect?
Comment: Only for the verb 'be'.

Feature: Are there conjugation classes?
Are there verbal affixes or clitics that turn intransitive verbs into transitive ones?
Comment: The suffix -ti- turns the intransitive verb into transitive, e.g. tupany 'fix, fit' vs. tupatiny 'repair'.

Feature: Is there a phonologically bound reflexive marker on the verb?
Comment: The suffix -śki- turns a transitive verb into reflexive, e.g. dyśany 'put (something) on' vs. dyśaśkiny 'dress oneself'.

Feature: Is there a phonologically bound reciprocal marker on the verb?
Do verbs classify the shape, size or consistency of absolutive arguments by means of incorporated nouns, verbal affixes or suppletive verb stems?
Is there a copula for predicate nominals?
Are there serial verb constructions?
Can mood be marked by an inflecting word ("auxiliary verb")?
Can aspect be marked by an inflecting word ("auxiliary verb")?
Can tense be marked by an inflecting word ("auxiliary verb")?
Is verb compounding a regular process?
Are there verb-adjunct (aka light-verb) constructions?
Comment: karyny 'do': with infinitives from Russian, some ideophones, routines and nouns.

Feature: Is incorporation of nouns into verbs a productive intransitivizing process?
Is there an existential verb?
Are different posture verbs used obligatorily depending on an inanimate locatum's shape or position (e.g. 'to lie' vs. 'to stand')?
Is there a notably small number, i.e. about 100 or less, of verb roots in the language?
What is the pragmatically unmarked order of S and V in intransitive clauses?
Comment: See also GB126.

Feature: Is a pragmatically unmarked constituent order verb-initial for transitive clauses?
Is a pragmatically unmarked constituent order verb-medial for transitive clauses?
Is a pragmatically unmarked constituent order verb-final for transitive clauses?
Is the order of constituents the same in main and subordinate clauses?
Comment: There is no principal difference in word order between an subordinated and a non-subordinate clause.

Feature: Do clausal objects usually occur in the same position as nominal objects?
Comment: The verb can precede the clausal object.

Feature: Is the order of core argument (i.e. S/A/P) constituents fixed?
Can standard negation be marked clause-finally?
Can standard negation be marked clause-initially?
Is there a difference between imperative (prohibitive) and declarative negation constructions?
Is verbal predication marked by the same negator as all of the following types of predication: locational, existential and nominal?
Is there a morpho-syntactic distinction between predicates expressing controlled versus uncontrolled events or states?
Is there a morphological passive marked on the lexical verb?
Comment: The suffix -śky- is primarily reflexive but it can turn transitive auditory and visual perceptive verbs 'see' and 'hear' into passive 'be seen', 'be heard'.

Feature: Is there a morphological antipassive marked on the lexical verb?
Comment: The suffix -śky- is primarily reflexive but it can be used as an antipassive marker with some verbs.

Feature: Is there a morphologically marked inverse on verbs?
Is there clause chaining?
Is there an overt verb marker dedicated to signalling coreference or noncoreference between the subject of one clause and an argument of an adjacent clause ("switch reference")?
Is there a morphologically marked distinction between simultaneous and sequential clauses?
Comment: The suffix -sa is used for simultaneity and precedence of the action; the suffix -ku for simultaneity only.

Feature: Are causatives formed by affixes or clitics on verbs?
Comment: The suffix -ti- for causatives

Feature: Is there a causative construction involving an element that is unmistakably grammaticalized from a verb for 'to say'?
Comment: However, the complementizer šuysa deriving from the verb 'say' can be used in reason and purpose constructions (Klumpp 2016:540)

Feature: Are verbs reduplicated?
Comment: Total reduplication of a verb can express the longer duration of an imperfective non- pluractional event (Asztalos et al. 2019).

Feature: Are nouns reduplicated?
Comment: At least, inflected nouns can be reduplicated, expressing a higheer quantity of a quality (augmentative): kužmyś-kužmyś baśtyny 'strength.ELA-strength.ELA take-INF' 'to take away with all his/her might.' It seems that mainly nouns with quantificational semantics and numeratives are productively reduplicated, e.g. kyrymen-kyrymen 'by bits', ćuren-ćuren 'in rows', etc.

Feature: Are elements apart from verbs or nouns reduplicated?
Comment: Adjectives and adverbs reduplicated to express a superlative-like meaning.

Feature: Is there productive morphological trial marking on nouns?
Is there productive morphological paucal marking on nouns?
Is there a logophoric pronoun?
Can an adnominal property word agree with the noun in gender/noun class?
Can an adnominal demonstrative agree with the noun in gender/noun class?
Can an article agree with the noun in gender/noun class?
Can the verb carry a marker of animacy of argument, unrelated to any gender/noun class of the argument visible in the NP domain?
Can an adnominal property word agree with the noun in number?
Can an adnominal demonstrative agree with the noun in number?
Can an article agree with the noun in number?
Is there any productive diminutive marking on the noun (exclude marking by system of nominal classification only)?
Comment: Although see Napol'skich 2003:296, e.g. suffixes -ok (nyl 'girl' > nylok 'little/dear daughter'), -aš (pi 'boy, son' > pijaš 'little/dear boy'). According to Napol'skich (2003:296), these suffixes may also be "a kind of vocative suffixes."

Feature: Is there any productive augmentative marking on the noun (exclude marking by system of nominal classification only)?
Is there a gender system where a noun's phonological properties are a factor in class assignment?
What is the order of adnominal property word and noun?
Is there a male/female distinction in 2nd person independent pronouns?
Is there a male/female distinction in 1st person independent pronouns?
Can an adnominal numeral agree with the noun in gender/noun class?
What is the order of the adnominal collective universal quantifier ('all') and the noun?
Do collective ('all') and distributive ('every') universal quantifiers differ in their forms or their syntactic positions?
Comment: They differ formally byde 'every', bydes 'all' and in the order possibilities: both UQ-N  for 'all' and only UQ-N for 'every'

Feature: Can predicative possession be expressed with a transitive 'habeo' verb?
Can predicative possession be expressed with an S-like possessum and a locative-coded possessor?
Comment: With the postposition dor-yn 'at-INE'

Feature: Can predicative possession be expressed with an S-like possessum and a dative-coded possessor?
Can predicative possession be expressed with an S-like possessum and a possessor that is coded like an adnominal possessor?
Comment: A possessor is in GEN.

Feature: Can predicative possession be expressed with an S-like possessor and a possessum that is coded like a comitative argument?
Can polar interrogation be marked by intonation only?
Can polar interrogation be indicated by a special word order?
Is there a clause-initial polar interrogative particle?
Is there a clause-final polar interrogative particle?
Is there a polar interrogative particle that most commonly occurs neither clause-initially nor clause-finally?
Comment: A polar interrogative particle typically occurs on the focus of the questioned constitent.

Feature: Is there a comparative construction that includes a form that elsewhere means 'surpass, exceed'?
Is there a comparative construction that employs a marker of the standard which elsewhere has a locational meaning?
Can comparatives be expressed using two conjoined clauses?
Is there a comparative construction with a standard marker that elsewhere has neither a locational meaning nor a 'surpass/exceed' meaning?
Is there a bound comparative degree marker on the property word in a comparative construction?
Is there a non-bound comparative degree marker modifying the property word in a comparative construction?
Can polar interrogation be marked by a question particle and verbal morphology?
Can polar interrogation be indicated by overt verbal morphology only?
Can polar interrogation be marked by tone?
Is there a phonologically or morphosyntactically definable class of ideophones that includes ideophones depicting imagery beyond sound?
Can polar interrogation be indicated by a V-not-V construction?
Can standard negation be marked by an inflecting word ("auxiliary verb")?
Can standard negation be marked by a non-inflecting word ("auxiliary particle")?
Does the verb for 'give' have suppletive verb forms?
Is there an inclusory construction?
Is there a phonologically free passive marker ('particle' or 'auxiliary')?
Is there a phonologically free antipassive marker ('particle' or 'auxiliary')?
Comment: See GB148.

Feature: Can the agent be expressed overtly in a passive clause?
Comment: Only impersonal constructions allow the overt Agent marking (see exx. 9b, 10b in Gulyás and Speshilova 2014:68, 70).

Feature: Is there a phonologically independent reflexive pronoun?
Is there a phonologically independent non-bipartite reciprocal pronoun?
Are there multiple past or multiple future tenses, distinguishing distance from Time of Reference?
Comment: none of the past tenses seem to indicate the difference between the Time of Reference.

Feature: Is there overt morphological marking on the verb dedicated to mood?
Are there special adnominal possessive pronouns that are not formed by an otherwise regular process?
Can augmentative meaning be expressed productively by a shift of gender/noun class?
Can diminutive meaning be expressed productively by a shift of gender/noun class?
Is singular number regularly marked in the noun phrase by a dedicated phonologically free element?
Is dual number regularly marked in the noun phrase by a dedicated phonologically free element?
Is plural number regularly marked in the noun phrase by a dedicated phonologically free element?
Is trial number regularly marked in the noun phrase by a dedicated phonologically free element?
Comment: There is only SG vs. PL distinction.

Feature: Is paucal number regularly marked in the noun phrase by a dedicated phonologically free element?
Is there a large class of nouns whose gender/noun class is not phonologically or semantically predictable?
Is there grammatical marking of direct evidence (perceived with the senses)?
Is there grammatical marking of indirect evidence (hearsay, inference, etc.)?
Comment: The perfect (participle) form vylem of the verb 'be' is used as the inferential marker. The perfect tense can also be used with evidential overtones, signaling that the speaker has not witnessed the event. The verbal form vylem can also form analytic past tenses, where it also carries evidential overtones (Winkler 2011:98).

Feature: Is there an interrogative verb for content interrogatives (who?, what?, etc.)?
Is there a count/mass distinction in interrogative quantifiers?
Do (nominal) content interrogatives normally or frequently occur in situ?
Can the relative clause follow the noun?
Can the relative clause precede the noun?
Are there internally-headed relative clauses?
Comment: This is attested in Beserman Udmurt.

Feature: Are there correlative relative clauses?
Comment: This is attested in Beserman Udmurt.

Feature: Are there adjoined relative clauses?
Is there a decimal numeral system?
Is there synchronic evidence for any element of a quinary numeral system?
Is there synchronic evidence for any element of a vigesimal numeral system?
Is there a body-part tallying system?
Are all person categories neutralized in some voice, tense, aspect, mood and/or negation?
Is there a class of patient-labile verbs?
Does the verb for 'see' have suppletive verb forms?
Does the verb for 'come' have suppletive verb forms?
Is there any accusative alignment of flagging?
Comment: Definite objects acquire accusative marking, while indefinite objects remain unmarked.

Feature: Is there any ergative alignment of flagging?
Is there any neutral alignment of flagging?
Comment: Indefinite objects remain in the nominative case like the subject of the clause.

Feature: Is there a politeness distinction in 2nd person forms?
Is there a preposed complementizer in complements of verbs of thinking and/or knowing?
Comment: The preposed Russian complementizer čto is replicated into Udmurt and can be used with verbs of thinking and/or knowing instead of the autochthonous complementizer šuysa (see Tanczos 2013; Klumpp 2016).

Feature: Is there a postposed complementizer in complements of verbs of thinking and/or knowing?
Can adnominal possession be marked by a prefix on the possessor?
Can adnominal possession be marked by a prefix on the possessed noun?
Can adnominal possession be marked by a suffix on the possessor?
Comment: Both the genitive and the ablative cases occur as markers of the possessor.

Feature: Can adnominal possession be marked by a suffix on the possessed noun?
Can mood be marked by a non-inflecting word ("auxiliary particle")?
Comment: The optative is expressed by means of the particle med + FUT.

Feature: Can aspect be marked by a non-inflecting word ("auxiliary particle")?
Comment: Analytical past tenses use the particalized verbal form val.

Feature: Can tense be marked by a non-inflecting word ("auxiliary particle")?
Comment: Analytical past tenses use the particalized verbal form val.

Feature: Can the S or A argument be omitted from a pragmatically unmarked clause when the referent is inferrable from context ("pro-drop" or "null anaphora")?
